questions.text: Why does this product exist?
questions.findings: No clear product vision. Team is unclear about objectives and jumping to solutions without understanding the problem. Operating as a feature factory with stakeholders dictating features.
questions.notes: Leadership doesn't communicate strategy. Team feels like order takers.

questions.text: Who are the users and customers?
questions.findings: We haven't talked to customers in 6 months. Team has no direct customer contact. All insights filtered through sales and support tickets. No customer interviews or research conducted.
questions.notes: Last user research was 6+ months ago. Relying on secondhand information.

questions.text: What is the current state of the product/market?
questions.findings: Product has grown organically without clear strategy. Competitor analysis is outdated. Market positioning unclear. Churn rate increasing but team doesn't know why.
questions.notes: Data shows declining engagement but no investigation into root causes.

questions.text: What are the business goals and constraints?
questions.findings: Business goals exist but aren't shared with team. Team doesn't understand revenue model or how their work impacts business outcomes. Working in the dark.
questions.notes: PM knows business goals but hasn't communicated to engineers.

questions.text: What problem does this solve for users?
questions.findings: Confusing checkout flow causing 40% cart abandonment. Users report frustration but team hasn't observed actual usage. Need quick validation before engineering investment. No usability testing conducted.
questions.notes: Analytics show the problem but team hasn't talked to users to understand why.

questions.text: How will we measure success?
questions.findings: No clear success metrics defined for most features. Too many features fail post-launch. No way to validate if customers will actually use features before building. Shipping features into the void.
questions.notes: Team tracks deployment velocity but not customer outcomes.

questions.text: What value does this create?
questions.findings: Unclear value proposition. Features are built because stakeholders ask for them, not because they solve validated customer problems. No value testing or validation.
questions.notes: Team can't articulate why customers would care about most features.

questions.text: What are the key assumptions?
questions.findings: Many unvalidated assumptions. Team assumes they know what customers want. Assumptions documented but never tested. Features shipped based on hope.
questions.notes: Created assumption list in workshop but no plan to validate them.

questions.text: Who owns this product decision?
questions.findings: Hidden stakeholders control decisions. Unclear decision-making authority. PM has title but no real empowerment. Decisions reversed at last minute by executives.
questions.notes: Culture of HiPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion). PM feels powerless.

questions.text: What is the team structure and composition?
questions.findings: Team of 1 PM, 4 engineers, 1 designer. No dedicated product trio. PM and engineer rarely collaborate on discovery. Designer only involved for UI work, not discovery.
questions.notes: Siloed work. No cross-functional collaboration on problem definition.

questions.text: How does this team work with other teams?
questions.findings: Dependencies on platform team create bottlenecks. No clear communication channels. Teams work in isolation. Handoffs are painful.
questions.notes: Platform team is overwhelmed. Feature teams wait weeks for support.

questions.text: What is the current development process?
questions.findings: Agile theater - standups and sprints but no empowerment. Two-week sprints filled with stakeholder requests. Delivery cadence is good but outcomes are poor.
questions.notes: Going through motions of agile without the mindset shift.

questions.text: What are the team dynamics and capabilities?
questions.findings: Team has skill gaps and needs development. No time for discovery because roadmap is packed. New to discovery practices. Engineers willing but PM doesn't know how to lead discovery.
questions.notes: Good team culture but lacking product skills and practices.

questions.text: What organizational constraints exist?
questions.findings: Feature roadmap dictated from above. Loss of autonomy. Team can't say no to stakeholders. Waterfall planning process disguised as agile. Quarterly planning locks team in.
questions.notes: Organization says they want empowered teams but structure prevents it.

questions.text: What cultural factors influence this work?
questions.findings: Risk-averse culture. Failure is punished. Innovation theater - talks about innovation but rewards playing it safe. Executives want transformation but resist changing how decisions are made.
questions.notes: Culture change needed before practices can change.

questions.text: What stakeholder dynamics are at play?
questions.findings: Competing stakeholder priorities. Sales, marketing, and support all want different features. No clear prioritization framework. Loudest voice wins. Political decision-making.
questions.notes: Stakeholder alignment is critical blocker. Need stakeholder testing approach.

questions.text: What hypotheses need validation?
questions.findings: Built list of hypotheses but no validation plan. Team doesn't know how to test assumptions. Need framework for assumption testing. Continuous discovery would help but team doesn't practice it.
questions.notes: Workshop identified 20+ critical assumptions. Zero have been tested.

questions.text: What are the biggest risks?
questions.findings: Biggest risk is building wrong things. Technical feasibility is fine but value and viability are questionable. Need discovery sprints to derisk before committing engineering.
questions.notes: Team confuses technical risk with product risk. Strong engineering, weak discovery.

questions.text: What evidence exists to support this direction?
questions.findings: Evidence is weak. Anecdotes from sales calls. Support tickets. No systematic customer research. No prototypes tested. No value validation. Betting on opinions.
questions.notes: Team needs to learn how to gather and evaluate evidence.

questions.text: What alternatives were considered?
questions.findings: First idea is only idea. No ideation or exploration of alternatives. Opportunity solution tree would help but team jumps straight to solutions. Need to slow down and explore problem space.
questions.notes: Jumping to solutions is cultural norm. Need structured ideation.

questions.text: How will we learn and iterate?
questions.findings: No learning loop. Features are shipped and forgotten. No post-launch review. No continuous discovery practice. Team needs coaching on building discovery muscle.
questions.notes: Ship and forget mentality. No feedback loops established.

discovery.name: Customer Interviews
discovery.description: Qualitative discussions with customers to discover opportunities. Pro tip: bring engineer along.
discovery.whenToUse: You can never do too many. Essential for understanding customer problems and needs.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "haven't talked to customers"
Discovery findings align with: "need user insights"

discovery.name: Team Objective
discovery.description: Frame work as desired outcome, not list of features. What business results are we trying to achieve?
discovery.whenToUse: Start of any significant work. Essential for moving from feature factory to empowered team.

discovery.name: Opportunity Assessment
discovery.description: Four questions: What business objective? How will we measure success? What customer problem? What alternatives did we consider?
discovery.whenToUse: Before committing to build anything significant. Validate business case and customer value.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "jumping to solutions"

discovery.name: User Prototype
discovery.description: Simulation of user experience requiring no engineering. Test with users before building.
discovery.whenToUse: Rapid internal iteration and user testing before engineering investment
discovery.timeCommitment: Hours to days (vs weeks to build real feature)
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "need quick validation"

discovery.name: Stakeholder Testing
discovery.description: Uncover business constraints before building. Which stakeholders need to approve? What are their concerns?
discovery.whenToUse: When viability risk is high. Before investing in solutions that stakeholders might block.

discovery.name: Continuous Discovery
discovery.description: Weekly touchpoints with customers. Build discovery muscle through consistent practice.
discovery.whenToUse: Ongoing practice for all product teams. Essential habit for empowered teams.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "too many features fail post-launch"

discovery.name: Assumption Testing
discovery.description: Identify and systematically test critical assumptions. Validate/invalidate before building.
discovery.whenToUse: When you have many unvalidated assumptions. Turn opinions into evidence.
discovery.timeCommitment: 1-3 weeks depending on number of assumptions

discovery.name: Discovery Sprints
discovery.description: One week sprint: understand problem deeply, explore solutions, prototype and test best ideas.
discovery.whenToUse: Time-boxed discovery for new problems. Great for teams new to discovery.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "new to discovery"
Discovery findings align with: "derisk before committing"

discovery.name: Opportunity Solution Tree
discovery.description: Visual map of opportunity space. Explore multiple solutions per opportunity before choosing.
discovery.whenToUse: When jumping to first solution. Forces exploration of problem and solution space.
discovery.timeCommitment: Ongoing tool (1-2 hours initial setup, weekly updates)
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "explore problem space"

discovery.name: Usability Testing
discovery.description: Watch users perform tasks with your product. Identify usability issues before launch.
discovery.whenToUse: When usability risk is high. Validate that users can actually use your solution.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "confusing checkout flow"
Discovery findings align with: "no usability testing"

coaching.name: Coaching Plan
coaching.description: Gap analysis and development plan. What skills does team need? What coaching approach?
coaching.whenToUse: Start of coaching engagement. Identify skill gaps and create development roadmap.

coaching.name: Coaching Time Management
coaching.description: Help team make time for discovery. Address 'too busy' objection. Discovery is part of work, not extra.
coaching.whenToUse: When team says 'no time for discovery.' Shift from reactive to proactive.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "no time for discovery"

coaching.name: Team Objectives - Empowerment
coaching.description: Coach team to work from objectives not feature lists. Shift from feature factory to empowered team.
coaching.whenToUse: When team operates as feature factory. Transition to outcome-focused work.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "loss of autonomy"

coaching.name: Coaching Decisions
coaching.description: Guide team's decision-making process. Help teams make evidence-based decisions confidently.
coaching.whenToUse: When team struggles with decisions or defers to HiPPO. Build decision-making capability.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "unclear decision-making authority"

coaching.name: Coaching Product Discovery
coaching.description: Guide team through discovery practices. Build discovery muscle through doing.
coaching.whenToUse: When team is new to discovery. Learn by doing with coach support.
matchReasons: Discovery findings align with: "new to discovery"
Discovery findings align with: "build discovery muscle"
